page.title: 03Newton Aycliffe-symbol
page.content: Newton Aycliffe is symbolised by an acorn which represents the oak forests which formerly covered this area.The old Saxon name"Acle",meaning"oak leaf" was the origin for the name Aycliffe. A grant of arms was made to Aycliffe Development Corporation in 1956. {CHEVRON}-represents St.Cuthbert's Way linking town and industry. {HAND GRENADE}-represents Royal Ordnance Factory. {OAK TREE}-ancient oak forests.{ {RED BACKGROUND,GOLD BORDER}-boundaries of the new town. {SHEAVES OF CORN}-from the Eden family shield.They owned the land. {LIONS AND GAUNTLETS}-the military ways of the old Bishops of Durham. A rebus"A"is formed by the chevron and a broken branch of an oak tree. {MOTTO}-Not the least but the greatest we seek.
